import numpy as np

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import scipy
source.047c6544:
df['No of Sellers'] = df['No of Sellers'].str.replace(' Sellers','', regex=True)
df
source.fdc41531:
df['No of Sellers'] = df['No of Sellers'].astype(int)
df['Rank'] = df['Rank'].astype(float)
df['Reviews Count'] = df['Reviews Count'].astype(int)
df['Price'] = df['Price'].astype(float)
source.c872c625:
sns.lmplot(x='Price', y='Reviews Count', hue='Rank', 
           data=df.loc[df['Rank'].isin([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 95, 96, 97, 98, 99])], 
           fit_reg=False)
source.ce5ee487:
sns.lmplot(x='Price', y='Reviews Count', hue='Category', 
           data=df, 
           fit_reg=False)
source.fb99bba6:
sns.lmplot(x='Price', y='No of Sellers', hue='Category', 
           data=df, 
           fit_reg=False)
source.d7456000:
sns.lmplot(x='Reviews Count', y='No of Sellers', hue='Category', 
           data=df, 
           fit_reg=False)
source.fee77e51: Some interesting trends we see here are that the video games category has twice as many sellers for each product than any other category along with twice the standard deviation, video games have the highest standard deviation for ratings, gift cards bought are around $50, and gift cards have more than 4 times the count of reviews compared to any other category and have the highest standard deviation.
source.c52bcd71: Thanks for reading through this notebook! If you learned something, remember to upvote! :)
source.1ff6bd68: Very interesting to see that products sold by 1 seller makes up the majority of the dataset.
source.c9dfc7e2: Not too much coorelation in the dataset. The highest coorelation for rank is price and reviews count. The highest coorelation for category is price, no of sellers, and reviews count.
source.b9359820: As expected, the cheaper products are more frequent in the dataset.
source.2f87997b: We are going to analyze the relation of each data point to rank and category.
source.f31e67ca: As expected, the dataset is mostly balanced in terms of categories
source.cfaa3730: As expected, the higher ratings are more frequent in the dataset, though 4.9 and 5.0 is less frequent than expected but this is most likely due to the scarcity of these ratings.
